excerpt: Granite & marble temple ruin built for the deceased Emperor Augustus in the 1st century A.D.
detail_description: The Roman Temple of Évora, located in the Conde Vila Flor square, is a remarkable ancient ruin built in the 1st century A.D. Initially dedicated to Emperor Augustus, it features impressive Corinthian pillars and stands as a symbol of Roman worship. Over the centuries, it served various purposes including as a mosque during the Moorish period and later as a market and slaughterhouse.
name: Roman Temple of Évora
address: Largo do Conde de Vila Flor, 7000-863 Évora, Portugal

excerpt: Completed in 1746, this prominent Roman Catholic cathedral offers scenic city views from the tower.
detail_description: The Cathedral of Évora, completed in 1746, is a prominent Roman Catholic cathedral offering scenic city views from its tower. It is one of the most significant cathedrals in Portugal and sits on the highest point of the city, making it a prominent feature of the cityscape.
name: Cathedral of Évora
address: Largo do Marquês de Marialva, 7000-809 Évora, Portugal

excerpt: The interior walls of this small, 16th-century chapel are lined with the bones & skulls of monks.
detail_description: The Chapel of Bones in Évora is a small 16th-century chapel adorned with the bones and skulls of monks, creating a haunting yet thought-provoking atmosphere. Located near Giraldo Square, it stands next to the famous Igreja de San Francisco cathedral. The chapel's walls are decorated with motifs created from the remains of 5,000 individuals collected from overcrowded cemeteries at the time.
name: Chapel of Bones (Évora)

detail_description: The University of Évora, established in 1559, is one of Portugal's oldest educational institutions. Initially managed by the Society of Jesus, it was later repurposed as the National High School of Évora until its reinstatement as a university in 1979. Situated in Évora, Portugal, the university boasts a historic campus with Renaissance architecture and the renowned Cloister of Espirito Santo.
name: University of Évora

excerpt: Tranquil cobblestone square featuring a 16th-c. fountain, terrace cafes & Gothic architecture.
detail_description: Praça do Giraldo is a charming cobblestone square in Evora, Portugal, known for its 16th-century fountain, Gothic architecture, and bustling atmosphere. Named after Geraldo Sem-Pavor (the Fearless), who played a significant role in ousting the Moors from the city in 1165, this square is a popular meeting place for locals and tourists. It features terrace cafes, boutiques under graceful arcades, and a lively weekend market.
name: Praça do Giraldo

excerpt: Stone aqueduct designed by Francisco de Arruda & built in the 1530s, with a path alongside it.
detail_description: The Agua de Prata Aqueduct, also known as the Evora aqueduct, is a stunning stone structure designed by Francisco de Arruda in the 1530s. Extending for nearly 9 kilometers through various parts of the city's historic center, this well-preserved water canal offers a picturesque path alongside it. The aqueduct showcases an elegant blend of old and new, with its rough stone construction seamlessly integrated into the modern town.
name: Aqueduct Água de Prata

excerpt: Neolithic-era monument featuring many stones standing upright in a circle, some with inscriptions.
detail_description: Located just west of Evora near Guadalupe, the Almendres Cromlech, also known as Cromleque dos Almendres, is a Neolithic-era monument dating back over 6,000 years. It is the largest megalithic site on the Iberian Peninsula and predates Stonehenge in England.
name: Almendres Cromlech
address: HW5Q+2G2, Nossa Sra. de Guadalupe, Portugal

excerpt: Évora is the capital of Portugal's south-central Alentejo region. In the city's historic center stands the ancient Roman Temple of Évora (also called the Temple of Diana). Nearby, whitewashed houses surround the Cathedral of Évora, a massive Gothic structure begun in the 12th century. The Igreja de São Francisco features Gothic and baroque architecture along with the skeleton-adorned Chapel of Bones.
detail_description: Evora, the capital of Portugal's Alentejo region, is a city steeped in history and culture. Its historic center boasts the ancient Roman Temple of Évora and the Gothic Cathedral of Évora, surrounded by charming whitewashed houses. The Igreja de São Francisco showcases stunning Gothic and baroque architecture, including the eerie Chapel of Bones adorned with skeletons.
name: Evora

detail_description: Giraldo Square Fountain is located in the central district and faces the basilica of St. Andrew. It was named after Giraldo the Fearless, who defeated the Moors in 1165 and became the governor of Evora. The square used to be a Roman market and was later renamed in his honor. The fountain originally sourced water from an aqueduct for public use in ancient times.
name: Giraldo Square Fountain

detail_description: The Jardim Público de Évora, also known as the Public Gardens, is a spacious green area located in the heart of Evora Old Town. It's conveniently close to several attractions such as the central market, Igreja de Sao Francisco, and Chapel of Bones. Visitors can take a leisurely stroll through the gardens or find a peaceful spot for a picnic with local delicacies like bread, cheese, and chourico sausage.
name: Jardim Público de Évora

detail_description: Igreja de São João Evangelista, also known as Igreja dos Lóios, is a remarkable monument characterized by the Manueline style. It is part of the Os Loios Convent and stands as an impressive old church in Evora.
name: Igreja de São João Evangelista / Igreja dos Lóios

detail_description: Nestled within the historic walls of Évora, the Cadaval Palace, or Palacio dos Duques de Cadaval, is a stunning 14th-century gem that offers visitors a glimpse into Portugal's rich heritage. Dominated by the striking Torre das Cinco Quinas (Five Corners Tower), this palace boasts an enchanting Jardim do Paço (Palace Garden) where you can unwind amidst lush greenery.
name: Cadaval Palace

detail_description: When visiting Evora, a city rich in history and architectural wonders, one must explore the charming Praca do Giraldo at its center. The well-maintained historic streets lead to various attractions such as the Castelo Velho, Cathedral, University of Evora, Aqueduct of Agua de Prata, Roman Baths, Chapel of Bones and more. Among these landmarks stands out the unique Renaissance-style Graça Church with its striking granite structure adorned with four colossal figures supporting globes.
name: Graça Church

excerpt: Monsaraz is a civil parish of the municipality of Reguengos de Monsaraz, on the right margin of the Guadiana River in the Portuguese Alentejo region, near its border with Spain. The population in 2011 was 782, in an area of 88.29 km². Wikipedia.
detail_description: Monsaraz is a charming civil parish located in the Alentejo region of Portugal, nestled on the right bank of the Guadiana River near the Spanish border. With a population of 782 inhabitants and covering an area of 88.29 km², this picturesque destination offers a serene escape for travelers. Renowned for its historical significance and scenic beauty, Monsaraz is a must-visit for those seeking an authentic Portuguese experience.
name: Monsaraz

detail_description: Alto de São Bento, just a short drive from Evora's old town, is a popular viewpoint offering stunning panoramic views of the city and its surroundings. Locals often visit for picnics or to enjoy the sunset in a relaxed atmosphere. The area also features little white windmills and a Museological Center dedicated to preserving natural and cultural heritage. It's an ideal spot for a leisurely walk with historical information available on-site.
name: Alto de São Bento

excerpt: Imposing Gothic-style church, known for its spooky chapel decorated with human skulls & bones.
detail_description: Igreja e Mosteiro de São Francisco is a Gothic cathedral in Evora, built in honor of St. Francis during the reign of Manuel I. Adjacent to the cathedral is the famous Chapel of Bones, constructed from human skulls and bones collected from overcrowded cemeteries. The chapel's walls are adorned with motifs and its white brick ceiling features death-themed frescoes.
name: Igreja e Mosteiro de São Francisco

excerpt: Alentejo Region is one of the seven NUTS 2 regions of Portugal. It covers all of the historical Alentejo Province and part of the historical Ribatejo and Estremadura provinces. Wikipedia.
detail_description: Alentejo, a region in Portugal, is known for its historical significance and natural beauty. It encompasses the Alentejo Province as well as parts of the Ribatejo and Estremadura provinces. The capital city, Evora, has been designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1986. The region boasts picturesque countryside adorned with cork trees and is renowned for its delicious cuisine and wine production.
name: Alentejo

excerpt: Charming, compact museum with a broad collection, from 18th-century fine arts to Roman artifacts.
detail_description: Museum Frei Manuel do Cenáculo in Evora is a charming and compact museum that offers a diverse collection spanning different eras. Named after an 18th-century monk and archaeologist who later became the archbishop of Evora, the museum showcases a wide array of artifacts, from ancient Roman relics to fine paintings from the 1900s.
name: Museum Frei Manuel do Cenáculo
address: Largo do Conde de Vila Flor, 7000-804 Évora, Portugal

detail_description: The Castle of Evoramonte, situated in Evora, Portugal, is a remarkable display of medieval military architecture with Renaissance influences. It sits atop a hill and provides breathtaking views of the surrounding Alentejo region. The castle features distinctive cylindrical towers and intricate knot-patterned decorations on its outer walls. Construction began in the 11th century around an existing temple, which was later restored in the 19th century.
name: Castle of Evoramonte
address: R. da Convenção 6, 7100-314 Évora Monte, Portugal

excerpt: Museum & shop with a collection of old-fashioned grandfather clocks, watches & other timepieces.
detail_description: The Clock Museum - Pole Évora is a delightful destination for anyone fascinated by the art of timekeeping. This charming museum showcases an impressive array of vintage grandfather clocks, watches, and various timepieces that span centuries. Visitors can explore hundreds of meticulously collected items that tell the story of horology through the ages. The museum's rich history is complemented by its knowledgeable staff, who are eager to share insights about each piece in their collection.
name: Clock Museum - Pole Évora
address: R. de Serpa Pinto 6, 7000-537 Évora, Portugal

detail_description: The Public Library Évora is housed in a 17th-century building near the Convento dos Loios. Established in 1805, it stands as one of Portugal's oldest and most extensive libraries, boasting a remarkable collection that includes 664 incunabula, over 6,000 printed books from the 16th century, handwritten documents, cartography, sheet music, and more than 20 thousand periodical publications.
name: Public Library Évora
address: Largo do Conde de Vila Flor 4, 7000-863 Évora, Portugal

detail_description: MADE, also known as the Museum of Crafts and Design, is a small museum located near the Chapel of Bones. Established in 2011, it showcases handcrafts and artworks from the local Alentejo area. The museum offers an interesting collection of relics, including items like an electric whisk from 2015. Visitors can explore well-organized exhibits and even purchase handcrafted souvenirs at the on-site shop.
name: Museum of Crafts and Design – MADE

detail_description: R. Cinco de Outubro, located in Evora, is a bustling street lined with charming local artisan shops offering a wide array of unique products. Visitors can browse through an assortment of items such as cork purses, accessories, magnets, postcards, local alcohol, hot sauce, hand creams and cosmetics. Additionally, one can indulge in the delightful experience of sampling a shot of Ginjinha served in an edible chocolate cup while exploring this vibrant area.
name: R. Cinco de Outubro

detail_description: Nestled in the vibrant Praca do Giraldo, Santo Antão Church is a must-see gem during your visit to Évora. This charming Renaissance church, with its striking white façade, stands proudly at the northern end of the square. As you approach, you'll be greeted by a stunning marble fountain crafted from a single piece of stone—a true testament to artistry. Inside, the church reveals its splendor with beautifully decorated chapels adorned with exquisite tiles that reflect local craftsmanship.
name: Santo Antão Church

excerpt: Redondo is a municipality in the District of Évora in Portugal. The population in 2016 was 6, 567, in an area of 369.51 km². Wikipedia.
detail_description: Redondo, located in the District of Évora in Portugal, is a charming municipality with a population of 6,567 spread across an area of 369.51 km². Just a 40-minute drive east of Evora, visitors can indulge in wine tastings at Herdade da Maroteira, a quaint estate known for its exquisite Cem Reis wine available in both red and white varieties. It's advisable to book your tasting experience in advance to ensure availability.
name: Redondo

detail_description: Enoturismo Cartuxa is a renowned winery in Alentejo, with a rich wine tradition spanning over 3000 years. Visitors praise the welcoming staff who provide informative tours and extra wine tastings, including the famous Pera Manca. The guided tours offer insights into the winery's history and include wine tastings, allowing guests to savor the exceptional wines. The on-site Enoteca (wine shop) offers an array of wines and knowledgeable staff to assist visitors.
name: Cartuxa - Quinta de Valbom - Fundação Eugénio de Almeida

detail_description: Menir dos Almendres is a megalithic site located in Portugal, featuring a collection of ancient standing stones. The site is believed to have been constructed around 6,000 years ago and is considered one of the oldest megalithic monuments in Europe. Visitors can explore the area and marvel at the impressive arrangement of large granite stones, some reaching over 3 meters in height.
name: Menir dos Almendres

detail_description: Jardim Diana is a charming garden located near the Roman Temple, offering a serene atmosphere for visitors to unwind and admire the surrounding scenery. The garden also features an array of statues, adding to its allure as a peaceful retreat in the heart of the city.
name: Jardim Diana

excerpt: Megalithic burial chamber carved into a hillside & constructed from gigantic granite slabs.
detail_description: Nestled near the historic city of Évora, the Great Dolmen of Zambujeiro stands as a testament to ancient engineering and communal practices from the late Neolithic period, around 4000-3000 BCE. This remarkable megalithic burial chamber is constructed from enormous granite slabs that create a striking stone chamber topped with an impressive capstone. As one of the largest dolmens in Europe, it offers visitors a glimpse into prehistoric rituals and burial customs.
name: Great Dolmen of Zambujeiro

detail_description: If you're planning an enotourism adventure, the Rota dos Vinhos do Alentejo is a must-visit destination in Évora. This charming hub offers visitors a wealth of information about local wineries and features complimentary tastings of exquisite Alentejan wines. With a rotating selection from various producers each week, you can explore unique flavors without spending a dime! Knowledgeable staff members are on hand to guide you through the tasting experience, sharing insights into the region's rich wine culture.
name: Rota dos Vinhos do Alentejo
address: R. Cinco de Outubro nº 88, 7000-854 Évora, Portugal

detail_description: In Evora, the Igreja da Misericordia stands out as one of the most stunning churches in the area. Built in the 16th century, its unassuming exterior belies a breathtaking interior adorned with a rococo marble door, golden altar, wall frescoes, and hand-painted blue and white azulejo tiles dating back to 1715.
name: Igreja da Misericórdia

detail_description: Ruínas Fingidas, or "Faux Ruins," may sound like a deceptive attraction at first, but it's actually a collection of constructed ruins made from pieces of real ruins found in the surrounding area. These faux ruins are roped off, preventing visitors from entering or climbing them, but they offer a picturesque and nostalgic sight within the beautiful park. While not historically significant themselves, these ruins contribute to the overall ambiance of the park.
name: Ruínas Fingidas

detail_description: Casa do Montado - Evora Cork Museum offers a multisensorial experience where visitors can explore the vineyards, winery, and wines produced in the land dedicated to Bacchus. The museum provides an interesting and educational look into the production of cork, offering detailed explanations on geology, trees, and cork production. It is well-organized with plenty of opportunities for exploration and also features locally produced gifts for purchase.
name: Casa do Montado - Evora Cork Museum
address: R. das Amas do Cardeal n.º2 1ºandar, 7000-581 Évora, Portugal

detail_description: Nestled in a picturesque landscape, the Roman Villa of Nossa Senhora da Tourega is a hidden gem that offers visitors a glimpse into ancient history. To preserve its integrity, access requires obtaining a key from a nearby house, which is an easy process. Once inside, you'll be amazed by the expansive ruins that exceed expectations and are surrounded by serene meadows filled with wildflowers and grazing sheep. The villa's location above the reservoir provides stunning views and several vantage points to explore.
name: Roman Villa of Nossa Senhora da Tourega

excerpt: Small museum in an old stable displaying 18th- & 19th-century carriages, harnesses & saddles.
name: Carriage Collection
address: Páteo de São Miguel, 7001-901 Évora, Portugal

detail_description: The municipal market in Évora is a great place to pick up cheese, olives, smoked meats, fruit and vegetables. There's also a small cafe near the southern end.
name: Mercado Municipal 1º de Maio - Évora

detail_description: The Arco Romano de Dona Isabel, also known as the Roman Arch of Evora, was a significant entrance to the city during the time of its first wall. This round arch, constructed at the end of the 2nd or beginning of the 3rd century AD, formed part of the Roman city of Ebora. Built with granite stonework and lacking its original watchmen, it stands as a historical and architectural marvel.
name: Arco Romano de Dona Isabel
address: R. de Dona Isabel, 7000-880 Évora, Portugal

detail_description: The Chapel of Saint Blaise is a stunning church that offers tranquility and beauty. Unlike other Catholic churches in Evora, it boasts unique and unusual architecture, reminiscent of a Disney creation. The opening hours may be unconventional, but this does not detract from its charm. The peaceful, wild abandoned garden within the church grounds provides an idyllic setting to relax and enjoy the serene atmosphere.
name: Chapel of Saint Blaise
address: R. de São Brás 2, 7005-150 Évora, Portugal

detail_description: The sculpture of Vasco de Gama, a renowned explorer and sailor from Portugal, is an exquisite work of art. The magnificent statue pays tribute to this extraordinary discoverer and navigator.
name: Estatua de Vasco de Gama

detail_description: Dona Dorinda Organic Wines offers an exquisite wine experience that would delight even the gods themselves. Their Syrah blend boasts a full-bodied expression that combines smooth elegance with opulent dark berry-cherry notes and herbaceous earthiness. The winery, situated amidst the green and gold hills of Alentejo, Portugal emphasizes quality over quantity in their vinho creation. Master vintner Victor Conceicao is committed to producing top-notch biological wines, which are grown sustainably on their estate.
name: Dona Dorinda Organic Wines
address: Quinta Nossa Sra da Conceicao Estrada de Arraiolos, 7000-744 Évora, Portugal

detail_description: Convento de Santa Clara is a historic site with a rich heritage and diverse offerings. The convent's encharcada, a traditional dessert, is a must-try for visitors. Additionally, the Enoteca Cartuxa wine bar provides an elegant setting to sample wines from one of Alentejo's finest wineries. The Pousada de Loios, located in the restored building of the former Convento de Sao Joao Evangelista, offers a pleasant atmosphere for relaxation.
name: Convento de Santa Clara
address: 505, R. de Serpa Pinto 70, Évora, Portugal

detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Évora, Jardim dos Colegiais is a charming garden that invites visitors to unwind amidst its lush greenery and vibrant flowers. This serene oasis offers a perfect escape from the bustling city life, featuring picturesque pathways and cozy benches where one can relax and soak in the tranquil atmosphere. The garden is adorned with historical elements that reflect the rich cultural heritage of the area, making it an ideal spot for leisurely strolls or quiet contemplation.
name: Jardim dos Colegiais

detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Évora, the Torre das Cinco Quinas is a stunning architectural gem that captures the essence of this historic city. Located near the Roman Temple and adjacent to Cadaval Palace, this imposing tower stands out against the backdrop of whitewashed facades, creating a picturesque scene. It symbolizes deeper meanings with its representation of faith, hope, charity, and even reflects the four seasons.
name: Torre das Cinco Quinas
address: R. do Menino Jesus 10, 7000-845 Évora, Portugal

detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Évora, the Igreja do Espírito Santo stands as a testament to the city's rich history and architectural beauty. Completed in 1574, this early Jesuit church features an inviting exterior adorned with seven granite arches that lead visitors into its spacious interior, which boasts ten side chapels. The church is not only a serene place of worship but also closely linked to the nearby University of Évora, adding to its cultural significance.
name: Igreja do Espírito Santo

excerpt: Renovated ancient monastery complex built between 1587 & 1598, occupied by monks since that time.
detail_description: The Convent of the Carthusians, also known as Mosteiro de Santa Maria Scala Coeli, is a historic monastery complex located just outside the old city walls of Evora. Originally built between 1587 and 1598, it was occupied by Carthusian monks until their expulsion in the 19th century. After being used as an agricultural school and later restored by the Eugenio de Almeida family, it now welcomes visitors for guided tours.
name: Convent of the Carthusians

detail_description: Casa de Garcia de Resende is a historic house in Evora, Portugal, once belonging to the renowned figure Garcia de Resende. The building features a Manueline style window that showcases the sophistication of the period and its association with talented artists. This unique structure is still inhabited today and holds significance as one of the symbols of Evora.
name: Facade of Garcia de Resende’s Home
Arena d'Évora
address: Av. Gen. Humberto Delgado, 7005-158 Évora, Portugal

name: Monument to the Dead of the Great War
